Q/A.question: What is KVM and what type of hardware does it require?
Q/A.answer: KVM is a full virtualization solution for Linux on x86 hardware containing virtualization extensions (Intel VT or AMD-V).    It requires x86 hardware with virtualization extensions.    It requires a modified QEMU.    The kernel component of KVM is included in mainline Linux as of 2.6.20.    It is a full virtualization solution.    It allows running multiple virtual machines.    It requires local disk space for the system image of the virtual machine.    It allows private virtualized hardware for each virtual machine.    It includes a loadable kernel module and a processor specific module.    It requires a network card, disk, and graphics adapter for each virtual machine.    It is a kernel-based virtual machine. Q/A.question: Describe the process to forward ports during virtual machine configuration in KVM.
Q/A.answer: Edit the XML file for the domain, add a <qemu:commandline> section, and insert <qemu:arg> lines to specify the port redirection, such as -redir tcp:2222::22.

How can faculty members and authorized users modify their public profiles on the UMIACS homepage?
Q/A.answer: Faculty members and authorized users can modify their public profiles on the main UMIACS homepage by using the ContentManagement system. They can log in at https://www.umiacs.umd.edu/user with their UMIACS username and password, and then click the "Edit" tab to make changes. Additionally, they can click the "UMIACS staff" link to edit specific fields such as name, academic title, research focus, and more. Changes may not be visible for up to five minutes due to caching. This is because the site's URL is not being updated to reflect the new HTTPS protocol, but the actual data being transferred is still secure.    In such cases, the site's URL may appear as HTTP, but the connection is actually secure.    It's also worth noting that some sites may use a non-standard port number, such as 8443, to serve secure content.    In such cases, the URL may start with HTTPS, but the port number may be different from the standard port 443.    For example, https://example.com:8443/secure/page.    In this case, the connection is still secure, but the port number is non-standard.    Note that some sites may also use a self-signed certificate or a certificate that is not trusted by the user's browser, which can cause the connection to appear as insecure, even though the data being transferred is still secure.    In such cases, the user may see a warning message in their browser indicating that the connection is not secure.    It's worth noting that some sites may use a proxy server or a load balancer to serve secure content, which can also cause the connection to appear as insecure.    In such cases, the user may see a warning message in their browser indicating that the connection is not secure.    It's always a good idea to check the URL of a site to ensure that it starts with HTTPS and that the port number is the standard port 443, to ensure that the connection is secure. Q/A.question: What command should you use to transfer a single file to another directory?
Q/A.answer: cp Source Destination. If destination is omitted, it will make a copy of the file(s) in the current directory. Alternatively, use scp for transferring files between hosts. Example: scp foo.txt USERNAME@example1.umiacs.umd.edu:~/Documents.

Q/A.question: What is the format for the cp command when transferring a file?
Q/A.answer: cp Source Destination. If destination is omitted, it will make a copy of the file(s) in the current directory.

Q/A.question: What is the recommended command for transferring large amounts of data?
Q/A.answer: gtar.

Q/A.question: What command should be used to return a file from a remote host to your current directory?
Q/A.answer: scp USERNAME@example1.umiacs.umd.edu:~/Documents/foo.txt ~/Videos. Alternatively, you can use gtar to transfer the file and then copy it to your current directory. The gtar command would be gtar -C ~/Documents/ -xpvf archive.tar, and then you would copy the file to your current directory using cp. However, scp is the more direct and efficient method.

Q/A.question: What is an important note regarding the cp command?
Q/A.answer: The cp command should only be used for small file transfers. If you try to transfer a large amount it is possible that cp will not copy all the files over properly.

Q/A.question: What command is used to create an archive of two files in the current directory?
Q/A.answer: gtar -cpvf archive.tar file1 file2. Reply

Q/A.question: In the command 'gtar -C ~/Documents/ -xpvf archive.tar', what is the purpose of the '-C' flag?
Q/A.answer: The '-C' flag specifies the target directory for the extraction. In this case, it extracts the files to the ~/Documents/ directory.

Q/A.question: What does the dash '-' represent in the gtar command format for data transfer?
Q/A.answer: Standard output.

Q/A.question: Is project data storage shared by default with every host?
Q/A.answer: No. Project storage is not shared by default with every host. It is available from /fs/vulcan-projects and /fs/cfar-projects under a name that you provide when you request the allocation.    There is a separate directory for each project.    You can access the data from the directory where the project storage was allocated.    Project storage is fully protected. It has snapshots enabled and is backed up nightly.    If you are no longer in need of the storage allocation, you will need to relocate all desired data within two weeks of the end of the allocation period.    Staff will then remove the allocation.    If you do not respond to staff's request by the end of the allocation period, staff will make the allocation temporarily inaccessible.    If you do respond asking for renewal but the original faculty approver does not respond within two weeks of the end of the allocation period, staff will also make the allocation temporarily inaccessible.    If one month from the end of the allocation period is reached without both you and the faculty approver responding, staff will remove the allocation.    Project storage is available for up to 10TB for up to 180 days.    You can request project based allocations by contacting staff with approval from the Vulcan faculty manager (Dr. Shrivastava).    The data is stored in a read-only dataset storage available at /fs/vulcan-datasets.    The list of Vulcan datasets we currently host can be viewed here.    You can request project based allocations for up to 10TB for up to 180 days by contacting staff with approval from the Vulcan faculty manager (Dr. Shrivastava).    These allocations will be available from /fs/vulcan-projects and /fs/cfar-projects under a name that you provide when you request the allocation. Q/A.question: What does 'dns.address' in a URL represent?
Q/A.answer: The domain name or IP address of the server hosting the requested resource. Acceptable formats include fully qualified domain names (FQDN) or short domain names if the local name service resolver is configured to try certain subdomains. Optional port number can be included. Example: dns.address:port. Acceptable examples include example.com, example.com:80, or example.com:8080. If no port number is specified, the default port for the protocol is used. For example, if the protocol is http, the default port is 80. If the protocol is https, the default port is 443. If the protocol is ftp, the default port is 21. Q/A.answer: Copy the data to be processed to local disk space of the compute node(s) your job is assigned.

Q/A.answer: It reduces the load on the central file server and improves the performance of the process.

Q/A.answer: They are not backed up.

Q/A.question: What does NAS stand for in the context of this document?
Q/A.answer: Network Attached Storage.

Q/A.question: What are the two categories of Network Attached Storage mentioned?
Q/A.answer: Network Home Directory Local Storage, Network-Attached Local Storage.

Q/A.question: What is the purpose of the NAS as described in the text?
Q/A.answer: To provide personal storage for users.

Q/A.question: What type of account is a Collaborator account?
Q/A.answer: Sponsored provisional account.

Q/A.question: What access do Collaborator accounts provide?
Q/A.answer: Access to UMIACS applications such as GitLab, Object Storage, and MediaWiki instances.

Q/A.question: Do Collaborator accounts provide login access to UMIACS computers?
Q/A.answer: No.

Q/A.question: How is access to a group's resources managed for Collaborator accounts?
Q/A.answer: Through Security Groups, which can be managed in the UMIACS Directory Application.

Q/A.question: What is required for a Collaborator account to be created?
Q/A.answer: A UMIACS Account holder must sponsor the Collaborator Account. This is done in our UMIACS Requests Application. This will send an email to the Collaborator to set their details (including a username and password). Once the Collaborator has created their account, an email will be sent to both the account sponsor and the Collaborator that the account is ready to use.

Q/A.question: Where do you go to sponsor a Collaborator account?
Q/A.answer: The UMIACS Requests Application.

Q/A.question: What happens once a Collaborator has created their account?
Q/A.answer: An email will be sent to both the account sponsor and the Collaborator that the account is ready to use.

Q/A.question: What management actions are available for a sponsor regarding their Collaborators?
Q/A.answer: A sponsor can send a password reset email or remove their sponsorship. They can also view and take over sponsorship of Collaborators sponsored by users they sponsor.

Q/A.question: What does the 'Take Over Sponsorship' action do?
Q/A.answer: Transfers sponsorship of a Collaborator account to you. The original sponsor is notified. Staff is also notified.

Q/A.question: What is one of the password security policies regarding previously used passwords?
What can a sponsor do regarding the accounts they sponsor?
Q/A.answer: A sponsor can view a list of the accounts they sponsor, remove their sponsorship, or modify the expiration date, but these require staff action and are not immediate.  They can also request to remove their sponsorship or modify the expiration date.    They can also send a password reset to the collaborator.

Q/A.question: What action is required to secure a password according to UMIACS policy?
Q/A.answer: Choose a strong password, do not use your UMIACS password for any other service, and only connect using secure protocols. It is also your responsibility to secure your password.  Additionally, UMIACS staff members do not store your password in a retrievable format.  If you forget your password, you must reset it.  Passwords cannot contain (or match a substring of 3+ sequential characters) of your username or any part of your first or last name.  Passwords also cannot be previously used in your last 10 passwords, previously changed in the last 2 days, or compromised in a known data breach.  Passwords must be a minimum of 8 characters with at least 3 character classes (English uppercase characters, English lowercase characters, Base 10 digits, and Non-alphanumeric characters).  UMIACS has a policy of not sharing any UMIACS-affiliated account for any purpose.  Action may be taken against shared accounts.  You must also click on a link to verify your email address after submitting the account request form.  Your PI must also review and approve your account request.  Accounts can take anywhere from a few hours to a day for installation, depending on how quickly your PI approves your account.  You can change your password yourself if you know your current password, or have your account sponsor reset it for you if you do not know your current password.  If you are unable to physically stop by the UMIACS Help Desk, you can have your account sponsor work with the UMIACS Help Desk to receive a temporary password on your behalf.  The account sponsor will then be responsible for conveying the password to you in a secure manner.  You can also view a list of the accounts you sponsor in the UMIACS Account Management Web Application, and request to remove your sponsorship or modify the expiration date.  However, these actions require staff action and are not immediate.  It is also your responsibility to secure

Q/A.question: What is the primary purpose of UMIACS Class Accounts?
Q/A.answer: UMIACS Class Accounts support classes for all of UMIACS/CSD via the Nexus cluster.  Faculty may request that a class be supported by following the instructions here.

Q/A.question: What must students do if they do not receive an account notification email after their TA or instructor requests an account?
Q/A.answer: Renew their token through the student's class account request in the app. This will invalidate the old token and issue a new token and then send a new email for account redemption. The faculty/TAs can do this.

Q/A.question: How long do students have to redeem their account before the redemption token expires?
Q/A.answer: 7 days.    The token is only good for 7 days.    Once the student clicks the URL, they will be taken to a page to redeem their account.    If the student does not redeem their account within 7 days, Faculty/TAs can renew their token to send a new email for account redemption.    This will invalidate the old token and issue a new token.    The new token will be good for another 7 days.    This process can be repeated as many times as necessary.    If the student still does not redeem their account after 7 days, the Faculty/TAs will need to contact staff to advise on the steps.    Students will not be able to reset their password automatically in the event that they forget it if they do not provide a phone number when they redeem their account.    In this case, the TA will need to contact staff and staff will advise on the steps.    The Faculty/TAs will need to communicate any special instructions or information with their students on how to use the computational resources.    Class accounts also need to setup Duo multi-factor authentication in order to access the cluster.    Otherwise, they will see the message Access is not allowed because you are not enrolled in Duo.    Please contact your organization's IT help desk.    Have them follow the instructions here.    Once the account(s) are installed, they will be listed as installed on the class dashboard.    Each student will receive an email with information on getting started with their class account.    Class accounts are provided through our Nexus infrastructure with a specific partition of nodes.    Each class will need to have the faculty member or TA(s) as the point of contacts for the class.    All students within the class will need to raise issues or questions through these points of contact who can relay or request support through our HelpDesk.    Please refer to the ClassAccounts documentation for further information.    If you are a faculty member teaching a class and want to use our resources,

Q/A.question: What is required for logging onto the class submission host after account installation?
Q/A.answer: Registration in Duo. If you see the error "Access is not allowed because you are not enrolled in Duo. Please contact your organization's IT help desk.", you have not yet enrolled/registered in Duo. To register, visit our directory app and log in with your Class username and password. You will then receive a prompt to enroll in Duo. For assistance in enrollment, please visit our Duo help page. Once notified that your account has been installed and you have registered in our Duo instance, you can SSH to nexusclass.umiacs.umd.edu with your assigned username and your chosen password to log in to a submission host. If you store something in a local directory (/tmp, /scratch0) on one of the two submission hosts, you will need to connect to that same submission host to access it later. The actual submission hosts are: nexusclass00.umiacs.umd.edu nexusclass01.umiacs.umd.edu.

Q/A.question: How can a student request additional personal storage beyond the 30GB quota?
Q/A.answer: By having their TA or instructor contact staff. This storage will be located at /fs/class-projects/<semester><year>/<coursecode>/<username>.     Note: This is specific to Class Accounts, for general accounts, the process is different.    Also, note that the storage request must be made through the student's TA or instructor, not directly by the student.     The storage will be allocated at /fs/class-projects/<semester><year>/<coursecode>/<username> and will have a quota of 100GB.     The student's TA or instructor must contact staff to request the additional storage.     Once the storage is allocated, the student will be able to access it at the specified location.     The storage will have a quota of 100GB and will be used for project storage.     The student's TA or instructor must also specify the usernames of the accounts that should be in the group.     Only other class accounts in the same class can be added to the group.     The quota will be 100GB multiplied by the number of accounts in the group.     The storage will be located at /fs/class-projects/<semester><year>/<coursecode>/<groupname>.     The groupname will be composed of the abbreviated course code as used in the username, followed by "g", followed by the number of the group, padded with zeros to make the total group name 8 characters long.     For example, if the course code is "c999z" and it is the first group, the group name would be "c999zg00".     The storage will be used for group projects and will have a quota of 100GB multiplied by the number of accounts in the group.     The student's TA or instructor must contact staff to request the additional storage.     The storage will be allocated at the specified location and will be used for group projects.     The quota will be 100GB multiplied by the number of accounts in the group.

Q/A.question: What is the method of job scheduling that UMIACS Class Accounts must use for computational jobs?
Q/A.answer: SLURM workload manager.    The Class accounts only have access to the following submission parameters in SLURM: --partition - class, --account - class, --qos - default, medium, and high. They must specify at least the partition parameter manually in any submission command they run. If they do not specify any QoS parameter, they will receive the QoS default. They are restricted to 32 total CPU cores, 4 total GPUs, and 256GB total RAM across all jobs they have running at once.    They can view the resource limits for each QoS by running the command show_qos. The value in the MaxWall column is the maximum runtime they can run a single job for each QoS, and the values in the MaxTRES column are the maximum amount of CPU cores/GPUs/memory they can request for a single job using each QoS. Q/A.question: How can you add an additional path to your current PATH in Bash?
Q/A.answer: export PATH=${PATH}:/the/new/path. By moving around the ${PATH} you can control the order that programs are found in your path. Alternatively, you can use export PATH=$PATH:/the/new/path. Both of these commands will append the new path to the current PATH.

Q/A.question: What does the order of paths in the PATH variable affect?
Q/A.answer: The order of paths in the PATH variable affects the order that programs are found. The path is looked up left to right.

Q/A.question: What are the University's Data Retention Guidelines related to?
Q/A.answer: Cloud data storage retention policies vary based on the service provider. You can often buy additional storage or storage protection for a set price per renewal period. There is also sometimes a Trash folder that stores accidentally deleted data for some period of time, often 30 days. For services that UMD accounts specifically provide access to, the Division of IT (DIT) documents policies here.    UMIACS' Object Store retention is not handled by UMIACS, but decommissioned data is sent to Archives. Local data storage is retained by UMIACS staff in several ways, including snapshots, nightly backups, and archives.  Data is retained for up to 90 days, 1 week, and 5 years respectively. Q/A.question: How are SLURM jobs submitted for both interactive and batch jobs?
Q/A.answer: SLURM jobs are submitted using the srun command for interactive jobs and the sbatch command for batch jobs.    If you pass srun a normal shell command or a command that executes a script, it will submit a job to run that command on a compute node and then return. The sbatch command allows you to write a batch script to be submitted and run non-interactively on the compute nodes.     If you need to run a non-interactive submission that will remain running after you logout, you will need to wrap your srun commands in a batch script and submit it with sbatch.    The batch script will be run on the first node allocated as part of your job allocation and each job step will be run on whatever resources you tell them to.    The srun commands can also be more complex and be told to only use portions of your entire job allocation, each of these distinct srun commands makes up one "job step".    In the batch script, you can pass additional arguments into your sbatch scripts on the command line and reference them as ${1} for the first argument and so on.    The sbatch command also allows you to write a batch script with all of your resources/options defined in the script itself.    This is useful for jobs that need to be run tens/hundreds/thousands of times.    You can also use the salloc command to request resources be allocated without needing a batch script.    Running salloc with a list of resources will allocate the resources you requested, create a job, and drop you into a subshell with the environment variables necessary to run commands in the newly created job allocation.    When your time is up or you exit the subshell, your job allocation will be relinquished.    The scancel command can be used to cancel job allocations or job steps that are no longer needed.    It can be passed individual job IDs or an option to delete all of your jobs or jobs that meet certain criteria.

Q/A.question: What limitations do jobs in the scavenger partition have?
Q/A.answer: Jobs in the scavenger partition have no resource limits per job, but are subject to preemption rules. They are also limited to a maximum wall time per job of 3 days. Additionally, they are limited to 576 total CPU cores, 72 total GPUs, and 2304GB total RAM simultaneously across all jobs running with this job QoS.    In the scavenger-aarch64 partition, the total CPU cores and total RAM are 1600 and 281140MB respectively.    You are responsible for ensuring your jobs handle this preemption correctly.    The SLURM scheduler will simply restart a preempted job with the same submission arguments when it is available to run again.    Only contains x86_64 architecture nodes in the scavenger partition and aarch64 architecture nodes in the scavenger-aarch64 partition.    This job QoS is paired 1-1 with the scavenger partition.    To use this job QoS, include --partition=scavenger and --account=scavenger in your submission arguments.    Do not include any job QoS argument other than --qos=scavenger (optional) or submission will fail.    In the scavenger-aarch64 partition, to use this job QoS, include --partition=scavenger-aarch64, --account=scavenger, and --qos=scavenger-aarch64 in your submission arguments.    NOTE: These QoS cannot be used directly when submitting jobs, with the exception of the scavenger QoS.    Partition QoS limits apply to all jobs running on a given partition, regardless of what job QoS is used.    For example, in the default non-preemption partition (tron), you are restricted to 32 total CPU cores, 4 total GPUs, and 256GB total RAM at once across all jobs you have running in the partition. NIST is a non-regulatory agency, which means that it does not have the power to enforce its standards and guidelines. NIST has a number of programs and initiatives that promote innovation and industrial competitiveness, including the Advanced Technology Program, the Manufacturing Extension Partnership, and the Technology Innovation Program.    NIST also has a number of partnerships with other organizations and stakeholders, including the National Science Foundation, the Department of Defense, and the National Institutes of Health. Q/A.question: What does UMIACS prohibit with respect to passwords?
Q/A.answer: UMIACS prohibits using a password that has been previously compromised in a known data breach.

Q/A.question: How does UMIACS verify the validity of a new password?
Q/A.answer: UMIACS verifies the validity of a new password by checking if it has been included in a known data breach using the Have I Been Pwned (HIBP) corpus of passwords.     }}

Q/A.question: What is the data source used by UMIACS for checking compromised passwords?
Q/A.answer: Have I Been Pwned (HIBP) corpus of passwords.

Q/A.question: How many compromised passwords does UMIACS check against?
Q/A.answer: Hundreds of millions.

Q/A.question: What are the roles of the 'vulcan-dpart' and 'vulcan-scavenger' partitions?
Q/A.answer: The 'vulcan-dpart' partition is for guaranteed job allocations, while the 'vulcan-scavenger' partition is for jobs that are preemptable when jobs in other 'vulcan-' partitions are ready to be scheduled.

Q/A.question: What information is available in the 'Ordering Equipment' section?
Q/A.answer: Verbosity is preferred to lack of critical details. Ticket descriptions should contain a list of specific items being ordered. If priority shipping is required, please include that in the subject of the email. Quotes must include any applicable shipping costs. The purpose of the purchase (brief description) should be specified. If on sponsored funds such as federal grants, the description should also provide how the purchase relates to the purpose of the project. Wishlists or links to carts should not be included. Direct links to the items being ordered should be provided unless an official quote is attached. If ordering from numerous vendors, send one email per vendor. Otherwise, UMIACS staff will separate your request into different emails/Jira tickets after the fact. Priority shipping per vendor should be specified. If no shipping speed is selected, the lowest cost shipping that still provides tracking will be used. The account (KFS) to be charged should be specified. Please be as specific as possible. Account number is preferred, but if you don't know it, a specific description is OK. In the event that a single order has multiple accounts, list them all and specify which items are being charged to what accounts (or what percent of an item is being charged to an account) in the description. A PI (Principal Adviser) who has approved the purchase on the KFS account should be specified. In some cases, multiple PIs can charge to a single KFS account. A description of what you want to buy or provide it in a comment before you submit your order should be provided. When possible, provide a link to the item to be purchased. When purchasing through Amazon or a site that provides fulfillment for third party vendors, please state the specific vendor that is providing the item and at what price. Q/A.question: What permissions do files have by default when no umask is set?
Q/A.answer: 666 in binary or 110110110. Answer with the binary or decimal value.

Q/A.question: What binary representation corresponds to the default permission for directories when no umask is set?
How does the umask affect the permissions of files and directories created?
Q/A.answer: The umask determines the default permissions of files and directories created, and is used to subtract permissions from the default permissions.

Q/A.question: What is the result of applying umask 022 to the default directory permissions?
What does umask 002 allow for user and group permissions?
Q/A.answer: Full rwx permissions.

Q/A.question: What is the risk associated with using umask 000?
Q/A.answer: Security risk to you and your colleagues.

Q/A.question: Which command is used to set or check the current umask in a shell?
Q/A.answer: umask.

Q/A.question: Where can you set your umask to be applied by default each time you start a new shell session?
Q/A.answer: In your shell initialization file. For bash, this is.profile or.bash_profile, and for tcsh, it is.cshrc or.tcshrc.

Q/A.question: What command can be added to .bash_profile to set the umask to 002?
Q/A.answer: echo 'umask 002' >> ~/.bash_profile. Alternatively, the umask command can be added directly to.bash_profile. Answer should be one sentence.

Q/A.question: What is the most common variable mentioned that affects commands run in UNIX and Windows?
Q/A.answer: The PATH variable.

Q/A.question: How can you view your PATH variable in the shell?
Q/A.answer: You can view your PATH variable by using the built-in echo command in the shell, prefixing the variable with the $ sign. For example, type: echo $PATH.

Q/A.question: What is the correct syntax to append a path to the PATH variable in tcsh or csh?
Q/A.answer: setenv PATH ${PATH}:/my/new/path.

Q/A.question: What is the command to set the PATH variable in bash?
Q/A.answer: export PATH=${PATH}:/the/new/path.

Q/A.question: What steps should be taken to modify the Windows PATH Environmental Variable?
Q/A.answer: Go to Control Panel, click on User Accounts, then click on Change my environment variables, and edit the PATH variable. Click New if necessary and append the desired path, separated by semicolons. Click Edit and add the path to the end. Close and reopen the Command Prompt to verify the change.  Open a new Command Prompt and type in PATH to verify.  Alternatively, you can simply type PATH in the existing Command Prompt and verify the change.  If the PATH variable has not been modified properly, the updated PATH should not be printed.  If the PATH variable has been modified properly, the updated PATH should be printed.  To append the path to the end of the PATH variable, click Edit, and type the path followed by a semicolon.  If you are unsure about the steps, you can try typing PATH in the Command Prompt to verify that the PATH variable has been modified properly.  You can also try opening a new Command Prompt to verify the change.  If you are still unsure, you can try checking the User Variables for <username> to see if the PATH variable has been modified properly.  If it has not, you can try clicking New and putting PATH for the Variable name.  Then click Edit and append the location you are trying to add.  Different paths are separated by semicolons.  To verify that the PATH variable has been modified properly, open a new Command Prompt and type in PATH.  The updated PATH should be printed. If it has not, you can try opening a new Command Prompt and typing PATH.  The updated PATH should be printed.  If it is not, the PATH variable has not been modified properly.

Q/A.question: What two versions of compilers are supported on RedHat hosts according to the document?
Q/A.answer: The new Intel C/C++ Composer XE for Linux and Intel Fortran Composer XE for Linux, and some older versions of the C/C++ and Fortran compilers. (Note: The older versions are not specified in the second document) and the various versions of gcc compiled from source. (Note: The versions are not specified in the second document)

Q/A.question: What command is suggested to prepare the environment for C/C++ or Fortran compilation on RHEL7+/Ubuntu hosts?
Q/A.answer: module load intel/2020.1. However, note that the context mentions RHEL8+/Ubuntu hosts. Therefore, a more accurate answer for RHEL7+/Ubuntu hosts would be: module load intel/2018.2.2.

Q/A.question: What is the path for the Intel C/C++ compiler version 11.1 on RHEL7+/Ubuntu?
Q/A.answer: /opt/common/intel/Compiler/11.1/current.

Q/A.question: What command should tcsh/csh users execute to use the Intel C Compiler with the version 13.1.1 on a 64bit architecture?
Q/A.answer: source /opt/common/intel/composer_xe_2013_sp1.1.106/bin/iccvars.csh intel64. Then use the icc command.

Q/A.question: What are the paths for the Intel Fortran compiler version 11.1 on RHEL7+/Ubuntu?
Q/A.answer: /opt/common/intel/Compiler/11.1/current.

Q/A.question: For a tcsh/csh user using the Intel Fortran Compiler version 13.1.1 on a 64bit architecture, what command should be used?
Q/A.answer: source /opt/common/intel/composer_xe_2013_sp1.1.106/bin/ifortvars.csh intel64. Then, use the ifort command.

Q/A.question: What must be specified on the command line when sourcing the environment for either the Intel C/C++ or Fortran compilers?
Q/A.answer: The architecture, either ia32 for 32bit or intel64 for 64bit.
